Title:
Phylogeny of Nassella (Stipeae, Pooideae, Poaceae) Based on
Analyses of Chloroplast andNuclear Ribosomal DNA, and Morphology
Keywords:
ETS, ITS, plastid DNA, morphology, Nassella, phylogeny,
Stipeae
Abstract:
The genus Nassella, as currently circumscribed, includes
nearly 116 species distributed from Canada to Uruguay, Chile and
Argentina. Originally described as a subgenus of Stipa, it is one of the
largest genera in the tribe Stipeae. Within Stipeae Nassella is
characterized by its florets with a strongly convolute lemma, with a
conspicuous or inconspicuous crown at the apex, a short palea mostly
glabrous and without veins. Based on 53 species of Nassella and 22
outgroup species, we conducted phylogenetic analyses in order to test
the monophyly of Nassella, to study the relationships among its species
and with allied genera, mainly with Amelichloa and Jarava, to re-examine
infrageneric taxa previously included in Stipa and now considered within
Nassella, and to correlate the phylogenetic hypothesis with the
geographical distribution of the species. Two plastid (trnT-trnL and
rpl32-trnL) and two nuclear ribosomal (ITS and ETS) markers as well as
morphological characters were used. Our DNA data alone and combined with
morphology showed Nassella to be paraphyletic, with Amelichloa nested in
it. Jarava s.s. appeared either as sister group or in a polytomy
together with Nassella-Amelichloa. Two main clades were recovered,
which, although not morphologically homogeneous, are geographically and
ecologically distinguishable: one with species of Nassella distributed
in regions of high altitude from Bolivia and NW Argentina to Mexico and
northern South America; and the second, with the remaining species of
Nassella, and those of Amelichloa, concentrated in NW Argentina,
southern Bolivia, central Argentina and Patagonia, southern Brazil,
Uruguay, Paraguay and NE Argentina. Monophyly of Amelichloa, represented
by all five species, was strongly supported. None of Stipa subgenera,
now under the synonymy of Nassella, were recovered as monophyletic. Two
trends were observed: species originally included in subg. Pocostipa
gathered together in one of the main clades, while all sampled species
of subg. Stemmatostipa and subg. Stephanostipa were all included in the
other. The close phylogenetic relationship of Nassella and Amelichloa is
not consistent with the morphological differences between these
genera.
